content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and certainty, I would choose a strategy that maximizes the amount of money I can consistently earn over the 75 rounds. If we both play R or B consistently, we will each make 45$ or 40$ per round respectively, which averages to about 42.5$ for both choices.

However, if my opponent is rational and observes that I prefer security, they might try to exploit this by choosing R when I choose B and vice versa, in an attempt to maximize their earnings. In such a scenario, I would end up with 0$ in those instances where I chose B while they chose R. This could result in significant losses over the long run.

On the other hand, if I occasionally deviate from my preferred strategy (choosing B) when it appears that my opponent is following a consistent R strategy, I might be able to earn 35$ in those instances. While this is less than the 45$ I would earn if we both stick with R, it's better than losing 35$.

To minimize losses while still maintaining some level of consistency, I would choose a mixed strategy that occasionally deviates from my preference for R by choosing B as well. This could help prevent an opponent who is exploiting my preferences from earning too much at my expense. Therefore, I will choose B{B} to signal this mixed strategy.

It's important to note that the optimal strategy in this game depends on the opponent's behavior and their potential ability to observe and adapt to my strategy. If they cannot do so effectively, sticking with R would be more advantageous. However, given my preference for security and certainty, I will err on the side of caution and choose a mixed strategy that includes deviating from R occasionally.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Given that my opponent chose R in the previous round, they appear to be following a consistent strategy of choosing R. In this scenario, if I stick with my mixed strategy and choose B again, my opponent will earn 45$ while I only receive 35$, as observed in the previous round.

To avoid losing more money to my opponent's consistent strategy, I should deviate from my preference for B and choose R this time. This way, if my opponent continues with their R strategy, I will earn 45$, which is a better outcome than receiving 35$. If they adapt their strategy and choose B instead, I might still end up earning 0$, but at least in this round, I maximized my potential earnings given the information available. Therefore, I will choose R{R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, choosing R resulted in a loss of 35$ while my opponent earned 35$. Given that my opponent demonstrated they are willing to deviate from a consistent strategy of R by choosing B when I chose R, it's reasonable to assume they might continue doing so in the future.

To maximize my potential earnings, I should now choose B{B} as part of my mixed strategy. This way, if my opponent continues with their unpredictable behavior and chooses R again, I will earn 40$ (the payoff for both choosing B when the opponent chooses R). If they stick with their B strategy instead, I would still lose 5$, but this is a better outcome than losing another 35$ by choosing R.

It's also important to note that my mixed strategy helps maintain some level of unpredictability, which might make it harder for my opponent to consistently exploit my preferences and maximize their earnings at my expense.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both me and my opponent chose B, resulting in a payoff of 40$ for each player. This outcome reinforces my belief that choosing B as part of a mixed strategy can be beneficial when facing an unpredictable opponent.

Since we both earned the same amount in this round, it's not clear whether my opponent will continue with their unpredictable behavior or if they might revert to a more consistent strategy. In such uncertain situations, maintaining my mixed strategy remains the best course of action. I will choose R{R} as part of my mixed strategy to keep some level of unpredictability in my choices.

By continuing with my mixed strategy, I hope to maximize my potential earnings while making it difficult for my opponent to exploit my preferences and consistently earn more at my expense.
